Description: A yard stick is broken randomly into 8 pieces.  X = the distance (in yards) from one end of the stick to the 3rd break point.
parameter(s): alpha = 3; beta = 6
hint: break points are uniform over the stick

Description: Four of the 15 administrative assistants in an office have been trained in a new software program. Five of the 15 assistants are randomly selected to take part in a focus group about office procedures. X = the number of those in the focus group who have had the software training.

A 6.25-ounce tube of Crest toothpaste is used regularly by all members of a household until the tube is finished and then it is replaced by another tube of the same brand. X = how much toothpaste (in ounces) is in the current tube at a randomly chosen time.
hint: toothpaste used up at a constant pace

Description: X = how many of the next 20 customers at a hot dog stand have the correct change to pay for their purchases.
parameter(s): n = 20; p = probability that a random customer has the correct change
comment: Also approximately normal if p is not too small or too large

Description: Ohio's lemon law allows people who buy a lemon (a vehicle that turns out to be excessively defective) to return it for a refund. However, in Ohio, only about 24 cars are expected to be declared ?lemons" each year. X = the time until the next car is returned under Ohio's lemon law.
parameter(s): r = 24 per year (mean = 1/r=1/24 year or 1/2 month)
comment: alternate answer is Gamma with parameters 1 and 1/24

Description: X = the first number drawn (from the numbers 1 to 59) for this week's Powerball lottery.

A polling company gets respondents for a survey through random digit dialing.  However there is a large proportion of people, who are not available or refuse to answer the survey questions.  X=how many calls must be made before they get the first respondent.
parameter(s): p = probability that a person is available and willing to be interviewed when called

Description: A polling company gets respondents for a survey through random digit dialing.  However there is a large proportion of people, who are not available or refuse to answer the survey questions. The company needs a sample of 100 respondents in order to fulfill a contract. X=how many calls are made before they fulfill their contract.
parameter(s): k = 100; p = probability that a person is available and willing to be interviewed when called
comment: Also approximately normal if p is not too small

Description: The George Washington Bridge connecting New Jersey and New York is the busiest bridge in the world, carrying about 100 million vehicles a year.  On average, there is approximately one fatal accident per 20 million vehicles.  X = the number of fatal accidents on the George Washington Bridge next year.
parameter(s): lamda = 5
hint: fatal accidents are rare and close to indpendent of each other
comment: Poisson still reasonable even if the number of fatal accidents changes with the seasons of the year.

Description: X = How many people must be tested until you find 3 that have a B negative blood type.
parameter(s): k = 3; p = probabilitity that a random person has B- blood (about 2%)

Description: X = how many of each number you get when you roll a die 25 times

A radiation source causes the strand of DNA along a chromosome to randomly break into two pieces (i.e. one break point). X = the proportion of the way from one end of the strand to the other that the break occurs.
parameter(s): none (or A=0; B=1 in general uniform)

Description: The homicide rate in Miami Florida averages 1 per week throughout the year. X = the day when Miami will see it?s 10th homicide next year.
parameter(s): k = 10; theta = 7
comment: a.k.a. Erlang distribution in this case

Description: The USDA defines an ?Extra Large? egg as one weighing between 2.25 and 2.5 ounces.  Eggs are packaged by the dozen with 30 dozen to a case. X = the total weight (ounces) of the eggs in a random case delivered to a grocery.
parameter(s): mu = 855 ounces; sigma = 1.37 ounces
hint: sum of large number of  independent comparable parts
comment: Assume relatively uniform distribution of weights between 2.25 and 2.5 ounces per egg .  Otherwise can get bounds on mu and sigma that will be close to these values.

Description: X = How many people must be tested until you find someone with a B negative blood type.
parameter(s): p = probabilitity that a random person has B- blood (about 2%)

Description: The George Washington Bridge connecting New Jersey and New York is the busiest bridge in the world, carrying about 100 million vehicles a year.  On average, there is approximately one fatal accident per 20 million vehicles.  X = the time (in years) until the next fatal accident on the George Washington Bridge.
parameter(s): r = 5 per year (mean = 1/r = 1/5 year)
comment: Assumption of constant rate may not be appropriate (affects the mean - but exponential distribution still likely to be reasonable)

Description: Emergency call-boxes are systematically placed 1 mile apart along the Pennsylvania Turnpike where cell phone service is very spotty. Your car breaks down suddenly as you are driving east on the Pennsylvania Turnpike though luckily you had been keeping an eye out for the call boxes before your breakdown.  X= the distance you will need to walk to reach the closest call-box.
hint: no preference for any particular place to break down

Description: Emergency call-boxes are systematically placed 1 mile apart along the Pennsylvania Turnpike where cell phone service is very spotty. Your car breaks down as you are driving east on the Pennsylvania Turnpike so you walk eastward until you reach a call-box.  X= the distance in miles you will need to walk to reach the next call-box.
parameter(s): none (or A=0; B=1 in general uniform)
hint: no preference for any particular place to break down

Description: X = How many people have a B negative blood type in a sample of just one randomly selected person.
parameter(s): p = probabilitity that a random person has B- blood (about 2%)
hint: variable can only be zero or one
comment: alternate answer is Binomial with n=1

Description: There were 29 national polls published in the week before the 2012 U.S. Presidential race to gauge the voter support for President Barrack Obama and former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney.  Before the results of these polls were known: let X = the average percentage of the two-party vote amongst respondents that favor the President?s bid for re-election across the 29 polls.
parameter(s): mu = percentage of the two-party vote who favored the President's re-election for all voters;  sigma^2 = sum of variances for individual polls/841
hint: each of the 29 individual polls had a large sample size
comment: assumes the average bias across all polls is negligble

Description: X = the number of broken links in a randomly selected  page in Wikipedia
parameter(s): lamda = average number of broken links per page in all of Wikipedia

Description: 20 high school students apply for a summer job delivering pizza and 12 of them own a car.  Five of the students are picked randomly and called in for an interview. X = how many of the interviewed students own a car.

A small auditing firm does random checks on accounts and assigns cases that show irregularities to an accountant for further study.  X = how many accounts are checked before all five of the firm's accountants have a case for review.
parameter(s): k = 5; p = probabilitity that a random account shows irregularites

Description: Ten % of the jobs run on a computer take up 90% of the processing time and 10% of those top 10% take up 90% of the time dedicated to those jobs, etc? X= the time taken by a randomly selected job.
parameter(s): k = log(10)/log(9)

Description: X = the number of gallons of gas purchased by the next 100 customers at a service station
parameter(s): mu = 100*average amount purchased; sigma=10*st.dev of amounts purchased
hint: sum of gas purchased by independent customers

Description: X= the number of premature infants weighing less than 4 pounds are born tomorrow at the Cook County Hospital maternity ward in Chicago
parameter(s): mu = average number of premature infants per day
hint: number of rare events in a fixed tme period

Description: An online store only sells desktop computers, laptops, and tablets. X = how many of each type of machine will be in their next 100 sales
parameter(s): n=100; p1=probability that the next machine sold is a desktop; p2=probability it's a laptop; p3=1-p1-p2

Description: X = the differnce between the time to the next call to a customer service line and the time to the call after that.
parameter(s): mu = 0; b = average time between calls
hint: difference between X1= time to event governed by large independently acting population and independent X2 = time to same type of event

Description: X = the ratio of the time to the next major plane crash and the time between now and the one after that.
parameter(s): none (or A=0; B=1 in general uniform)
hint: time between plane crashes is nearly memoryless

Description: X = how many of the next 20 cars that pass you on the highway are silver colored
parameter(s): n=20; p= population proportion of passing cars that are silver

Description: X = how many cars pass you on the highway before one of them is silver colored
parameter(s): p= population proportion of passing cars that are silver
hint: each passing car is another trial

Description: A popular restaurant is completely full every Friday night.  X = the ratio of the variance of the amount of salt the restaurant will use on Friday nights this month compared to next month.
parameter(s): df1 = number of Fridays this month minus 1; df2 = number of Fridays next month minus 1
hint: What distribution models total salt use from Friday to Friday?

Description: A popular restaurant is completely full every Friday night.  X = the amount of salt the restaurant will use next Friday night.
parameter(s): mu = average amount used on Friday nights; sigma = standard deviation of amounts from Friday-to-Friday
hint: sum of amounts used by approximately constant number of nearly independent customers

Description: X = the number of calls to a customer service line in the next hour.
parameter(s): mu = call rate per hour
hint: number of events governed by large independently acting population

Description: Three horses are randomly picked from the 12 competing in a race and you place a bet on each of these three horses to win the race.  X=the number of winning tickets purchased.

Three horses are randomly picked from the 12 competing in a race and you place a bet on each of these three horses to show (i.e. come in first, second, or third).  X=the number of winning tickets purchased.
hint: chosen horses each hold separate position

Description: When you wake up tomorrow morning you look at the digital clock next to your bed and watch it until the time changes. X = how long you have to wait in minutes
parameter(s): none (or A=0; B=1 in general uniform)
hint: no time within the minute you awaken is more likely than another

Description: 40 subjects taking part in an experiment on the effect of exercise on happiness record how many times they laugh during the day before and the day after taking part in an active exercise program. Assuming the program has no effect on happiness, let X = the average difference between the recorded laughter values before and after the program.
parameter(s): mu =0; sigma^2 = variance of difference for individuals divided by 40
hint: with no effect expect no difference

Description: 80 subjects taking part in an experiment on the effect of exercise on happiness record how many times they laugh during the day before and the day after either taking part in an education program on the value of exercise (40 random subjects) or taking part in an active exercise program (40 random subjects). Assuming neither program has an effect on happiness, let X = the ratio of the average difference between the recorded before and after laughter values for those in the education program versus the average difference for those in the exercise program.
parameter(s): no parameters; or regular cauchy with parameters 0 and 1
comment: note same variance for numerator and denominator
